words.meaning: To overbalance or become unsteady and fall.
examples: The strong winds threatened to topple the old tree.
The protestors managed to topple the statue of the dictator.

words.meaning: Severe physical or mental suffering.
examples: He was in torment after breaking his leg.
The constant bullying was a source of torment for the child.

words.meaning: Mentally or physically inactive; lethargic.
examples: The hot weather made him feel torpid and lazy.
After the large meal, he fell into a torpid state.

words.meaning: A state of physical or mental inactivity; lethargy.
examples: The long, dark winter days induced a state of torpor.
He shook himself out of his torpor and went for a run.

words.meaning: A twisting force that tends to cause rotation.
examples: The mechanic applied extra torque to tighten the bolt.
The engine delivers a high amount of torque at low speeds.

words.meaning: Very hot and dry.
examples: They had a torrid affair that ended in heartbreak.
The torrid summer heat was unbearable.

words.meaning: Full of twists and turns.
examples: The tortuous mountain road was difficult to navigate.
He gave a tortuous explanation that was hard to follow.

words.meaning: Relating to a system of government that is centralized and dictatorial and requires complete subservience to the state.
examples: The country was ruled by a totalitarian regime.
The novel '1984' depicts a chilling totalitarian society.

words.meaning: In a humorous or insincere way.
examples: He made a tongue-in-cheek comment about her new haircut.
The article was a tongue-in-cheek look at modern dating.

words.meaning: To attempt to sell (something), typically by pestering people in an aggressive or bold manner.
examples: The company touted its new product as a revolutionary breakthrough.
He was touting for business outside the train station.

words.meaning: Attempted to sell (something), typically by pestering people in an aggressive or bold manner.
examples: The new movie was touted as the blockbuster of the summer.
He was touted as the next big thing in the music industry.

words.meaning: Poisonous.
examples: The factory was releasing toxic waste into the river.
She was in a toxic relationship that was damaging her mental health.

words.meaning: (of a person or animal) easy to control or influence.
examples: The new puppy was very tractable and easy to train.
The problem was not as tractable as they had first thought.

words.meaning: The transmission of customs or beliefs from generation to generation, or the fact of being passed on in this way.
examples: It is a family tradition to have a big dinner on Sundays.
The company has a long tradition of producing high-quality products.

words.meaning: A person who betrays a friend, country, principle, etc.
examples: He was branded a traitor for selling secrets to the enemy.
She felt like a traitor for revealing her friend's secret.

words.meaning: To tread on and crush.
examples: The crowd trampled the flowers in the park.
He would not let anyone trample on his rights.

words.meaning: Free from disturbance; calm.
examples: The tranquil lake was a perfect place for meditation.
She led a tranquil life in the countryside.

words.meaning: To be or go beyond the range or limits of (something abstract, typically a conceptual field or division).
examples: The beauty of the music transcended words.
He hoped to transcend the limitations of his humble beginnings.

words.meaning: To infringe or go beyond the bounds of (a moral principle or other established standard of behavior).
examples: He transgressed the law and was punished accordingly.
She had transgressed against the unwritten rules of their society.

words.meaning: An act that goes against a law, rule, or code of conduct; an offense.
examples: His transgressions were many, and he was eventually caught.
She asked for forgiveness for her transgressions.

words.meaning: Lasting only for a short time; impermanent.
examples: The transient beauty of the cherry blossoms is a reminder of the fleeting nature of life.
He was a transient worker, moving from one city to another in search of employment.

words.meaning: Not permanent.
examples: Fame can be transitory, so it's important to stay humble.
The pain was transitory and soon passed.

words.meaning: (of a substance) allowing light, but not detailed images, to pass through; semitransparent.
examples: The translucent curtains let in a soft, diffused light.
The wings of the dragonfly were translucent and delicate.

words.meaning: To change in form, nature, or substance.
examples: The alchemists tried to transmute lead into gold.
Her creative vision transmuted the ordinary into the extraordinary.

words.meaning: Painful or laborious effort.
examples: The pioneers endured great travail on their journey west.
She went through the travail of childbirth.

words.meaning: A false, absurd, or distorted representation of something.
examples: The trial was a travesty of justice.
The movie was a travesty of the book it was based on.

words.meaning: Guilty of or involving betrayal or deception.
examples: The treacherous friend betrayed his trust.
The treacherous mountain pass was covered in ice.

words.meaning: Resembling treacle in consistency, taste, or appearance; overly sentimental.
examples: The movie's treacly ending was predictable and uninspired.
Her treacly compliments seemed insincere.

words.meaning: A written work dealing formally and systematically with a subject.
examples: He wrote a learned treatise on the history of philosophy.
The new treatise on international law was highly anticipated.

words.meaning: An involuntary quivering movement.
examples: A slight tremor ran through her body as she spoke.
The earthquake caused a tremor that shook the entire city.

words.meaning: Shaking or quivering slightly.
examples: Her voice was tremulous with emotion.
He gave a tremulous smile, trying to hide his fear.

words.meaning: Vigorous or incisive in expression or style.
examples: She made a trenchant and witty critique of the new play.
His trenchant analysis of the situation was eye-opening.

words.meaning: A general direction in which something is developing or changing.
examples: The latest trend in fashion is to wear vintage clothing.
There is a growing trend towards healthier eating.

words.meaning: A feeling of fear or agitation about something that may happen.
examples: He approached the haunted house with great trepidation.
She felt a sense of trepidation before her job interview.

words.meaning: A cause of great trouble or suffering.
examples: The family faced many tribulations after losing their home in the fire.
He endured his tribulations with courage and resilience.

words.meaning: Unimportant or trivial.
examples: Don't waste my time with such trifling matters.
He was fined a trifling amount for the parking violation.

words.meaning: (of a remark, opinion, or idea) overused and consequently of little import; lacking originality or freshness.
examples: His speech was full of trite clich√©s and empty platitudes.
The plot of the movie was trite and predictable.

words.meaning: Of little value or importance.
examples: They argued over a trivial matter that was not worth fighting about.
The damage to the car was trivial and easily repaired.

words.meaning: An agreement between enemies or opponents to stop fighting or arguing for a certain time.
examples: The two warring factions agreed to a temporary truce.
Let's call a truce and stop arguing for a while.

words.meaning: Eager or quick to argue or fight; aggressively defiant.
examples: The truculent child was always getting into fights at school.
He had a truculent and confrontational attitude.

words.meaning: To shorten (something) by cutting off the top or the end.
examples: The article was truncated to fit on a single page.
His speech was truncated due to a lack of time.

words.meaning: Shortened by or as if by having a part cut off; cut short.
examples: The truncated version of the film was missing several key scenes.
He gave a truncated and incomplete account of the events.

words.meaning: A private, romantic rendezvous between lovers.
examples: The lovers arranged a secret tryst in the park.
She was late for their tryst, and he was getting impatient.

words.meaning: (especially of a part of the body) swollen.
examples: His ankle was tumid and painful after the sprain.
The river was tumid and overflowing its banks.

words.meaning: A loud, confused noise, especially one caused by a large mass of people.
examples: The tumult of the crowd was deafening.
Her mind was in a tumult of conflicting emotions.

words.meaning: Making a loud, confused noise; uproarious.
examples: The tumultuous applause lasted for several minutes.
The country has had a tumultuous history, marked by wars and revolutions.

words.meaning: (of a liquid) cloudy, opaque, or thick with suspended matter.
examples: The turbid water of the river was not safe to drink.
His turbid and confusing explanation left everyone more bewildered than before.

words.meaning: Characterized by conflict, disorder, or confusion; not controlled or calm.
examples: The country has had a turbulent political history.
The turbulent waters of the ocean crashed against the shore.

words.meaning: Swollen and distended or congested.
examples: The river was turgid and brown after the heavy rain.
His writing style was turgid and difficult to read.

words.meaning: To reverse a situation, so that one now has the advantage over someone who previously had the advantage.
examples: The underdog team managed to turn the tables on their rivals and win the championship.
She turned the tables on her accuser by revealing his own dark secrets.

words.meaning: Depravity; wickedness.
examples: The criminal was convicted of acts of moral turpitude.
He was a man of great turpitude who cared for no one but himself.

words.meaning: A vigorous struggle or scuffle, typically in order to obtain or achieve something.
examples: The two boys got into a tussle over a toy.
There was a brief tussle for the ball between the two players.

words.meaning: Serving as a protector, guardian, or patron.
examples: The ancient Greeks believed in tutelary deities who protected their cities.
She had a tutelary role in the young artist's career.

words.meaning: More than one string to one's bow means more than one interest, skill, or resource that one can use.
examples: She is a talented musician and a skilled writer, so she has two strings to her bow.
It's always a good idea to have two strings to your bow in case one plan doesn't work out.

words.meaning: A beginner or novice.
examples: He was a tyro in the world of finance, but he was eager to learn.
The experienced chef patiently taught the tyro how to chop vegetables.

words.meaning: Present, appearing, or found everywhere.
examples: Mobile phones are now ubiquitous in modern society.
The company's logo is ubiquitous, seen on billboards and advertisements all over the city.

words.meaning: Existing beyond what is obvious or admitted; intentionally hidden.
examples: He had an ulterior motive for helping her, which was to get her to invest in his business.
She suspected that there was an ulterior reason for his sudden kindness.

words.meaning: Being or happening at the end of a process; final.
examples: The ultimate goal of the project is to create a sustainable source of energy.
His ultimate ambition was to become a famous actor.

words.meaning: Offense or annoyance.
examples: She took umbrage at his sarcastic remark.
He was quick to take umbrage at any criticism of his work.

words.meaning: Without any reduction in intensity or strength.
examples: The storm continued with unabated fury.
His enthusiasm for the project remained unabated despite the setbacks.
